review_title: FedEx is a GREAT company & has been named one of Indianapolis'  Top Work Places by The Indy Star since 2009.
pros: You have the opportunity to experience a variety of job duties/ skills/ settings & can get extra hours if you choose to (especially Nov.-Dec.). They train & promote FAIRLY from within the company WITHOUT UNION/  DUES! The work offers plenty of exercise & a great team environment! If there's something you dislike about your job/ location/ shift/ group, then following a predetermined waiting period (length depends on position/ available openings), you are free to bid on another position/ location of your choice. They offer excellent benefits/ incentives ( medical, dental, optical, 401K, paid vacation, bonuses, up to $3,000/ yr toward tuition reimbursement, flight/ hotel/ rental car/ cellphone service discounts, & more)! FedEx employs a very diverse group of people, including some who are hearing impaired. You can attend/ get involved with our many community/ charity events. GREAT job security = NO LAY-OFFS to date! High pay rate for PT work. EXCELLENT opportunity for students!
cons: The work can be physically demanding. You sometimes have to work in extreme temperatures, as some positions are located on the warmer upper level, some are on the cooler lower level, & some positions are located outside. They have a "park-n-ride" shuttle to the facility & a tight security entrance (some areas require a 2nd shuttle within the facility), so you have to allow for that extra time to be sure you can clock in on time. This can range from 15-25 minutes before your start time! They don't allow cellphones or jewelry (except a watch &/ or wedding ring) inside the facility (few exceptions). There are very few FT positions available.

pros: I like physical jobs. Workers are down-to-earth and generally very friendly. Pays well and benefits for part time work. Multiple shifts to choose from, around the clock. Because the turnover is so high, there's a good chance you might move up in the company.
cons:
Sometimes I don't feel like I'm actually getting into better shape, as much as I'm just suffering from repetitive injuries. Even when you're doing everything "right" the package per hour output expectations are so high that it becomes dangerous. This is a company that talks about safety all the time, but really just expects you to do whatever it takes to get the job done.

 Management and trainers are very focused on numbers and productivity and not so focused on their people. "Get those package per hour rates up" and "don't waste company time," are the only messages  I receive. 

Anxious micro managers and people with anger issues are the norm the higher up in the company you go. I witnessed a higher up angrily literally screaming at the top of his lungs across the facility at an employee, like a crazy person. My trainer followed me around constantly correcting every tiny behavior, even things that are up to personal interpretation, even after 2 weeks of being employed.

job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros:
1. GREAT corporate culture and feeling of belonging without feeling like a cult 
2. Unbelievable job security 
3. Overall company ethics are good
cons:
1. HORRIFICALLY political environment and bureaucratic.  Small minded, Memphis mentality goes into all decisions on every level

2. Jobs don't correlate to reality of what a person should do--salespeople don't really sell, they are more account managers who do glorified admin work (e.g. invoicing, claims, chasing packages) and marketing is really product development--at ANY other company, the product development functions would be a prod development team and marketing would actually do MARKETING.  There is NEVER a reason for a marketing person to get a PMP certification....but they pretty much force you to do it.  

3. Once you become a manager, you are protected from any sort of criticism or feedback.  PULSE was a joke and they did away with it to where you couldn't even give management feedback.  They ended up watering it down to a "general" department talking session, which accomplishes nothing at all 

4. All good ideas must die at some point--no real chance to take ownership of a project and see it until the end.  

5. APEX has turned performance management into a nightmare.  They "recenter" you until your review fits into what your manager wants and they will make up bogus things to have you work on for the future.

job_title: Sales Executive in New York, NY
pros: The people here are amazing.
cons: In ten years u only receive the annual 1-3 percent raises as a gen x single woman I live paycheck to paycheck.  The beauty of the job was freedom and room to breathe. They now micromanage u to death and monitor your every move.  So if u have a headache at 5 pm and want to enter your calls the next day.  Forget it they will hound u to a point that the lack of financial improvement is no longer tolerable.  Also, sent my director an email how I made another operating company at the company another 100k that I don’t get credit for and he ignored me. As a woman u r treated less than because u r not part of the boys club. Now this is just my region. Everywhere else I feel woman r respected. No one cares if u closed a 5 mil account net rev because that was yesterday.  No one ever recognizes what u do however it is noted to go somewhere else if u don’t like it.

pros:
Most of the time, depending on your manager at the time, you work with minimal supervision.  
     Meet many different types of people of different backgrounds.  
     Great opportunity for making new friends.  
     Flexibility to move around and earn extra hours in different departments.
     There many different short shift options, enabling flexibility to pursue things outside FX.
cons:
Over the past several years the health insurance FX offers has taken a drastic turn for the worse. 2014 is the worst yet. So much worse there has been consideration of whether to have it at all. 
     They used to provide excellent coverage, better than most other companies out there.  Now other companies far exceed.
     No raises over the past few years, except for certain "chosen" positions.
Reviews no longer have any impact on your a pay raise (if there were any).  No matter your performance now, everyone would receive the exact same percent.  A person of 20 years would receive the same percent as a 1 year worker no matter how good or bad you perform.  Raises based on performance reviews inspired people to work harder and strive.
No incentive to go above and beyond.
     Opportunity for advancement is low.  Policy does not favor advancement for those hoping to move up.  Positions for vertical movement have been slim, applicant pool high.  FX years of experience mean little to nothing in who receives the position.

review_title: An IT Perspective of FedEx as a Company
pros: The schedule is VERY flexible.  If you have to run an errand or leave early for an appointment its fine.  This is a place where management actually cares about its employees.  Recently with the economy going through a rough patch it would have been very easy to layoff people, right before Christmas no less.  Instead, upper management took the biggest salary cuts and reduced our salaries by 5% and no one lost their job.  I eliminated my personal trainer (a luxury item) to make up the difference in pay.  No big deal whatsoever.  I have the ability to work from home if necessary.  This is a very laid back place to work where if you are talented and get your work done on time you will be successful.  People who are self-motivated and hard-working will definitely love this company.  You will be rewarded for your hard work.  I would say about 90% of management is promoted from within the organization.
cons: This is not a technology company so any projects you work on are driven by a business need and not a technology need.  You will not invent the next "gizmo" here.  This is more a place where you take the "gizmos" other people create and implement them in a way that makes sense to the company's business needs.  If you are a technophile who has to be involved in the latest and greatest cutting edge projects stay in Silicon Valley.

pros:
Excellent brand name recognition - you won't have to explain to anyone where you work or have worked if you decide to move on.
Very good benefits - not as good as they used to be but medical and other costs are going up for everyone.
Corporate culture breeds pride in the company and most employees bleed purple for it.
Work/life balance.
Fairly stable job situation even when times are not so good.
Fred Smith founded the company and built everything from the ground up. This really means something, you have to find out for yourself.
Regardless of the downsides listed, this review is a definite net positive. I highly recommend FedEx as a good place to work.
cons:
Bonuses and other compensation lopsidedly favor the people on top.
Most of the management chain of command is often more focused on producing numbers and reports and looking good to the people above them.
In IT disagreement with directives from higher up are discouraged - people in such positions "retire early" or "leave to pursue other opportunities"; this results in no negative feedback ever going up the chain for improvements and reduction of waste and overhead. Needless to say, everything that comes down from the CIO "succeeds".
The company relies heavily Fred Smith's [excellent] business sense & judgment. When he leaves, there are very, very few in this company's upper echelons that can replace him with any probability of success. The most likely scenario when he retires is a slow but inevitable downward spiral and FedEx will be another corporate machine run on numbers.
Company is still extremely dependent on the state of the economy & price of oil.

job_title: Senior Systems Programmer in Memphis, TN
pros: FedEx is the best employer in the Memphis area among large companies.  You can work as hard as you want to.  The medical benefits are fair and unrivaled among companies in the area. The retirement programs are fair and effective if you use them.  Fred Smith is a great leader.
cons: I left after a 3 years when I found something better out of town.  The Legal department runs the company and is so risk averse that FedEx is way behind the curve in delivering solutions for customers.  The volatile prices of energy makes it difficult to plan project costs, and projects that are running great are frequently canceled because of cost reductions.  If you are in Services, there are not enough titles and salary bands are too wide to count on regular promotions.  IT's Directors and VPs are very weak leaders and there really isn't anyone among them that has a remarkable understanding of technology or business.  There are not enough young people at FedEx to learn from and cultivate them into leaders.  Memphis is an awful area to live and there's no talent to draw from it.

job_title: Package Handler Part-time in Dubuque, IA
pros: It's basically a work out for 4 to 5 hours straight. Be prepared to get very sweaty and dirty. I work with many good people. Management is awesome and even helps when lines get backed up and there is only 1 loader in the trucks. I love the fact we only work 4 to 5 hours a night but there is no way you could work this job doing 40 hours a week. By the end of every night, you'll feel like you just got done doing an obstacle course after doing a 5 mile run. Must be in shape.
cons: The pay where is I work is crappy. This particular location starts out at 8.92 an hour but you get raises every two months for the first 6 months. Be prepared to get injured ALOT and come home with many bruises. Trucks collect ice in the winter and the entire cabin is a skating rink so there is lots of slipping and pulling muscles. On occasion, loaders work a truck on their own, but the sorters send boxes down as if there are two loaders in a truck. The expectation is to load 400  boxes an hour and it doesn't matter what size and weight they are. Packages come in all shapes, sizes, and weights.

review_title: Good place to work if you have a good manager
pros: Good benefits, pension plan, vacation, competitive base salary, stability, corporate discounts everywhere, fair vacation/time off, flexibility, car allowance, work from home, make your own schedule, free cell phone, free lap top, and great car allowance plus mileage.
cons: FedEx is the definition of corporate america.  You are nothing but a number and there are 360,000 employees.  If you are looking for a sales job, this job is not for you.  I spend 80% of my time dealing with non sales issues such as invoice adjustments, tracking packages, software issues, pricing not loaded correctly, ect and 20% of my time selling.  I have been screwed so many times out of bonuses when I bring on an account that is "incorrectly aligned" or does not spend enough money to meet adjustment criteria.  This job looks great on your resume but long term you will realize you spend majority of your time dealing with problems not selling.  But to be fair, it's not that bad if you learn how to play the games and train your customers to utilize the customer service department instead of calling your cell phone every time they have a problem.

review_title: Overall decent company, run from Procurement
pros: Good benefits (medical, dental, FSA, HRA, etc.), most managers are flexible if you need to work from home for whatever reason, a lot of good co-workers overall.
cons:
They do not pay well compared to the same job title/description as other companies, which will continue to cause them to lose young talent. They never try to retain talent because it’s a legitimate strategy of the company to let people leave so they can bring in new people that are cheaper, clearly ignoring the volume of data out there showing how expensive turnover and re-hiring is. 
Specifically, the sourcing and procurement org in the FedEx services operating company is an absolute nightmare, and that’s putting it lightly. Egotistical management, severe lack of true leadership skills, disingenuous, disinterested in employee opinions, and rule with an iron fist. Many stakeholders want nothing to do with our management team, which makes an ICs life miserable. A large number of employees have jumped ship over the past few months, which is only going to continue based on the amount of current employees looking for new jobs.  But that’s ok, because new hires will be cheaper.

job_title: Technical Quality Architect in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
FedEx makes you feel like you make the world go around (later, you realize you actually do!) - you are taught to live something we call the Purple Promise that simply states "I will make every FedEx experience outstanding". Very soon, you realize that dock loaders, desk workers, strategists, individual contributors, managers and executives actually believe this stuff and care about not just getting the job done but they actually care how you felt before, during and after you did it!! Very strange to most people under pressure to perform but the level of buy-in at the highest levels of the company shows newcomers right away that this company truly puts people first. If you're not feeling good about doing something, they want to know why - genuinely and fix it before you proceed. 
Quality Driven Management - This program has roots into every nook and cranny of operations and IT. FedEx  truly believes in continuously improving to get better, finding better ways of doing things, being more efficient, gaining new skills and always pushing the boundaries of achievement while at the same time encouraging employees to live heavy family lives, taking vacations, flexible work from home options (mandatory 2 weeks of work from home) etc.
When you're feeling this good about your work and your contributions, I challenge you to put out poor work - you can't - it's not possible.
cons: There aren't enough observed national holidays - I think FedEx (being a worldwide deliver business) only observes 6 National holidays.

job_title: Field Sales Professional in Memphis, TN
pros: Excellent brand that gets you in the door with companies you call upon. Also helps to have the FedEx name at your back when you have to prospect for new business.  You have the ability to plan your days the way you want around your schedule, so work life balance is great.  The relationships you build are great because you're helping people with their business.  Competition is usually FedEx vs UPS.  Plenty of opportunities if you want to move around in the company.
cons: Onboarding is really poor. The training you receive is good on a corporate level, but there's so much to learn that it's a 'trial by fire' mentality while learning from your other reps in the area.  their plate is full, too, so if you don't have any team players, you could be screwed. It's a general consensus that you don't feel remotely comfortable until at least a year on the job. Expectations of calls per day is not set in stone, but it might come up if you're not performing and consistently closing business. If you thrive off of a team atmosphere and interaction with team members, this is not the job for you.  Perform or they won't hesitate to manage you out.

job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Collierville, TN
pros: Great company to work if you like work life balance.  The benefits used to be great many years ago, but its not too bad now either.  The salaries are very standard.  They pay enough for the kind of jobs they have.  If you are a software engineer who has enough skills to get by programming languages, understand a few design patterns, have basic knowledge of software engineering and prefer a laid back work environment, so you can have enough time for family this is the place to be.
cons: If you are highly innovative and spirited as an engineer, this place is a total letdown.  FedEx is a transporation based company, not a technology company.  Their ideas in innovation are still dated and go real slow in releasing the latest and greatest of products.  Their business model is highly process based, even though some departments take pride of releasing new products as services to existing customers.  Just as any large company, FedEx also has a lot of red tape and bureaucracy.  If you work in the company for a long time, you will be in the dangerous zone of letting your skills become obsolete or unused.  You have to make an effort on your own to stay up to date with the industry.

pros: There are many different groups in IT, so you can learn a variety of things by switching jobs within the company (but if the budget is frozen, you're stuck).  Stable job, you're not likely to get fired or laid off.  Good benefits.  Tuition reimbursement.  On-site classes by staff as well as vendors.  On-site gym and cafeteria.  The tech campus is located in a quiet residential area.  Some groups have a laid-back atmosphere, I see people having 6-hour work days and getting away with it.  However, there are teams that have strict deadlines and 70-hour work weeks.  It really depends on which group you're in.
cons:
I have heard that it is difficult to move up the ladder in the technical direction, so many people go into management to be able to advance their careers.  Sometimes policies such as time off and working from home are not clear, things are often done by personal arrangement with the manager.  
If you are a conservative married middle-aged Southern American, you'll feel right at home at FedEx.  If that description does not apply to you, you might have difficulty trying to fit in socially.  Again, this depends on your particular team, but if you're unlucky enough to be the opposite of this description, be prepared for the possibility of social isolation and fear of expressing your individuality.

review_title: FedEx Services is the best employer to work for in Memphis hands down.
pros: people come first - it is a family environment.  They don't lay people off.  They are commited to making everyone feel welcome.  The pay is good and the work is challenging.  Everyone is willing to help and no question asked is stupid.  There are ample opportunities for growth and moving up in the organization.  You write your own way - if there is something you want to do, they allow you the freedom to take on that challenge and make it your own all the while engaging you with the right individuals to help you excel.  Everyone bleeds purple - company pride is apparent and infectious!
cons: There are some groups which are not as friendly.  Overall, this company is not as friendly as the last corporation where I was employed - I think this has to do with the international flavor of FedEx versus the last corporation where I worked most of the people were from the Southern US.  It often takes a while to find out who the correct people are to be working with on any given project because the company is so gigantic and along with that comes an enormous amount of red tape from legal and those processes many times hold projects up for an unecessary amount of time.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Decatur, GA
pros:
- Being able to work from one store to another sometimes.
- Nice uniforms. That was nice.
cons:
- 3-4 People can NOT handle a store on their own--especially in a congested area. We never had enough people to work on the floor
- We were expected to print, ship, AND provide sales on the floor. We had to clean our own bathrooms and try to provide customer service to those who want to print things on their own. It's IMPOSSIBLE.
- I remember being opening a store with my assistant manager and having 15+ people needing our assistance. Again. That is IMPOSSIBLE because we also provide print services. So we will have these long lines because we're working with customers that would require 15+ minutes of our time to assist them. Then we go and have to ship things for other customers. THEN we have to handle angry customers because they're waiting 30+ minutes just to buy a notebook. It's ridiculous and stressful and just. Ugh. It has been three years since I set foot to work in a Fedex store and it STILL was traumatic. I cried driving up there one time it was that bad.
- I didn't have proper training but was expected to just "figure it out" when dealing with customers placing a print order.
- Think twice about working in the retail store; or just don't do it.

review_title: Great company; size of organization makes it difficult to get things done
job_title: Business Systems Advisor in Dallas, TX
pros: Good company culture. Very diverse workforce (even near the top, although the very top still not quite there). Senior leadership typically makes great decisions, even in the face of significant challenges (for example when economy was struggling they chose to implement a 5% salary reduction combined with voluntary buyouts instead of layoffs). I work in technology, and they are finally realizing that they need to modernize their practices, which is resulting in some good changes. Immense/diverse opportunities, especially in Memphis. Great work/life balance (at least in my org).
cons: The fact that it is such a great and stable company makes for some complacent employees in some cases, and some groups are quite insulated/resistant to change. Every group is different, but it's not uncommon to find a team that just cruises and doesn't really try to push the envelope (including managers). Additionally, size of organization makes for a lot of overhead when trying to institute any kind of change, as there are many disparate groups/processes that must align. They historically haven't been stellar with integrating acquisitions; however, this is improving (particularly in relation to the TNT acquisition).

review_title: Great place if pay is not the most important thing
pros: I love FedEx because of the flexibility, work life balance and culture. I work with an amazing team, have the flexibility to be available for important moments for my child and ability to work from home. The benefits are amazing, and FedEx is one of few companies still offering a pension plan.
cons: The pay is not competitive with other large companies and it is not equitable. You must negotiate negotiate negotiate!  You also do not receive stock offering as with some other large companies. I have found that peers, some with less experience than myself, actually make a great deal more than me (10-20,000). Pay seems to be based on your ability to negotiate coming in the door and management's willingness to be fair. I don't want to say race/age plays much of a factor, but as with any large company there are some inequalities here as well. There is not much room to negotiate increases when promoted as there is a standard increase that is not based on performance. Bonus is based on performance but even this is political, and done via a ranking process against peers who are not even on the same team doing the same work.

review_title: Express,Ground,Freight and so-on dividend-up a profit to the Parent. The Services Division bills-out work with the firm.
job_title: Financial Analyst- Services Finance in Memphis, TN
pros: FedEx  is ...very big... on nudging employees to increase their knowledge-base. This action is required because the firm has sophisticated financial modeling tools that rely on its incredibly huge data-base, which covers its customer's shipping habits, and the corresponding costs. One example: An Services Department employee needs to become pretty well schooled with SQL and other database management tools. FedEx offers a number of "live" training classes in addition to on-line-based coursework, which greatly helps the employee develop or fine-tune code-writing skills.
cons: Required training session, either live or taught on-line, are often a big time-sink. This, particularly when the school session occurs during a workday. Project deadlines always loom, so the required training classwork... in a live classroom setting... can materially eat-away at a productive day. The on-line based training programs, particularly with database management, can be very arduous... the text-based product MUST BE VERY CLOSELY READ in order to move-up to the next module. A live training class would offer hands-on help quickly vs. a website-session that might require the student hours to catch-on to the same topic. However, the live classes are traditionally only during the workday.  I suggest offering evening and weekend "live" training sessions... particularly when it involves learning how to effectively use powerful but high degree of difficulty tools... like SQL.

review_title: Challenging with strong emphasis on global team work, have best work ethic, be systematic and focus on work-life balance
job_title: Senior Strategic Marketing Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: Management and HR have people first policy. Organization has teams with diverse ethnic and professional background which helps employees to develop strong conflict resolution, sportive spirit, relationship and team skills. Team members on many projects are spread across the country and on corporate projects members are drawn from international locations. This is both challenging for those that lack experience in working with large teams and helps develop project mgmt experience with national and international members. This company has very good reward system, tution reimbursement and many certification classes without charge. Professional growth, discipline, setting targets, goals and innovation is supported strongly through quarterly or monthly performance reviews using 1-on-1 sessions. Entire management has a candid open door policy for discussions that involve objectives, personal and professional growth with employees though it is important as professional ethics to schedule an appointment first. Also focus on work-life balance is wonderful. Management encourages innovation and loves "can do" positive attitudes. Also after work, I participated in more types of sports with other employees while working for this esteemed organization than in my entire adult and education life.
cons: Managers may appear to be hard to please on important projects since they want you to earn the professional and personal growth. Almost all of them balance it with a very good reward system. Middle and top management also challenge and demand performance from the managers equally. So better be prepared.

pros: Great brand recognition?   You don't get the door slammed in your face that's for sure.  If someone won't talk to a FedEx rep, they aren't doing their job! Excellent service to sell.
cons: No life balance.  Pay cuts 5% that we w I'll never get back. Benefits more expensive every yr.  dental vision difficult to find providers w/in network.  Sales goals so out of reach they are not attainable.  First yr since I've worked here that I will not make a bonus 0for 4 .   Many AEs in same boat. My take home has declined by $10k for two yrs in a row now.  Headed in wrong direction.   FedEx constantly changes and we've always said to just hng on because if something is going on that is bad, things will always change. But now we joke that e're afraid of what's next.   Big mistake combining FXF and parcel sales forces.  They've weakened the quality of the sales force by doing that, crowded territories and overloaded their sales force with too much to learn to be good at anything.

pros: Can't really think of any.
cons: The worst company I have ever had the displeasure of working for! The nepotism and cronyism are so vapid, that promotions, advancing to other departments are non-existent. People abuse 'working from home' and 'traveling' they never have to use their vacation days, because all they have to say is that they are WFH. Meanwhile, the people who are doing most all the grunt work are required to sit there from 9-6 watching others come and go as they please (example: they come in at 10am and leave around 2pm and yes, they take a lunch too). If someone is ever so privileged to have the title "manager" they get to do even less. Zero communication, which leads to constant chaos and stress. No dress code, people often dress like it is a Friday night club. Zero professionalism all around. When corporate comes to visit, they send emails (to about half of the company) telling them to dress up and show up to work. The company was started by some frat brothers so you can imagine the atmosphere. People walk around the office with their speakerphones on, other times they yell at each other (carry conversations) across the room rather than get up and talk or email. Some departments are grossly underpaid, meanwhile, new hires (friends and family) get a hefty payday. The building is disgusting nasty stains all over the carpet.

review_title: Anyone who knows Fred Smith will tell you that he will never need to beg for a bail out.
pros: I have worked for FedEx for most of my life. It has always been a good job. I love working outside, meeting people, getting exercise. After you have worked there a year, you can transfer to anywhere that there is a job posted.  You keep your seniority. I work in a small town, and work is hard to find here. I feel fortunate to be able to live in work in this small tourist town, when I know that many others have to endure a commute to the big city to make a decent wage. Fed Ex offers medical benefits, and  I will be getting a pension when I retire.

pros: 10 years ago FedEx was a place I was proud to contract trucks with.  It WAS a fun place to work.  The memory includes decent pay, a tire discount program, a maintenance program with bonuses.  and a decent run schedule.
cons:
Every year the FedEx  contract has taken from us.  We were forced to put workers comp on contracted drivers. FedEx never gave us revenue to cover this cost.  We were forced to make contracted drivers OUR employees.  FedEx didn't compensate us for the additional costs. The tire program was cancelled, The maintenance program with bonuses was cancelled.  I'm sure the fuel cards, fuel tax program and toll transponders are the next to go.  
  If you have an accident FedEx Ground will almost always say it was your fault.  Even if it goes to court and you win.  I've seen this happen.
   One of the drivers had prostrate cancer.  FedEx tried to disqualify him after his doctor ok'd him to return to work.  He's back to work but only after FedEx Ground was threatened with a law suit.   Local management is an embarrassment and disgrace..

review_title: It’s a job, but has gotten worse in recent years.
job_title: Courier/Swing Driver in West Valley City, UT
pros: Job security. Kind of. Better than being unemployed I guess, although if I was unemployed, I’d be earning more. Sad state of affairs, eh?
cons: Where to start. Severely delayed COVID-19 response. No hazard pay incentive - literally a t-shirt and a pin is what we’ve received. Inconsistent schedule - some days are 12 hours, some days you have literally nothing to do and are told to not come in. Poor communication from management. Inability to progress into management unless you are willing to relocate, and training is unpaid. Availability of trucks is a constant issue. Express packages now being handled by Ground for last mile optimization (less packages = less work). Inconsistent raises - supposed to be a step progression but nah, you’ll get 2% instead because corporate decided to dump tons of money into GPS and turn-by-turn directions on android tablets that don't work right (or at all) because they’re running off of maps from 2013. New employees given better vacation benefits and faster advancement, older employees don’t get any more vacation. Insurance is somewhat decent. Flight benefits aren’t worth it - you are literally last on the standby priority order. No a/c in some trucks during summer months and mechanics won’t fix it - same with heat in the winter.

pros: In sales, there is a relative sense of job security even when you are not that good.  There are nice benefits like car stipends and insurance.
cons: If you really want to succeed you simply must become like those above you.  While they may say they want people who "think-outside-the-box" I really don't think they really understand what that means.  Senior management in the -+55 age range are stifling growth and causing real talent to leave.  They would rather you go through the formalities and become a box checker as opposed to questioning why things are done how they are.  They are building the future based on the ideas of the past that have succeeded with no variation for today's world.  Middle management lacks any real backbone when it comes to allowing senior management to understand what is really going on.  You can come in as a great thinker with great ideas but you will soon see others getting promoted simply because they are more like the person above them.  The performance review is really somewhat of a joke.

review_title: Small fish in a very big pond... you are just a number here.
pros: There are some and always have been some great people that work at this company. I have built some long and lasting relationships with many of them.
cons:
For more than a decade this company has had a high rate of turnover and their management is well compensated when their employees are downsized and given pay cuts. The company has a good year and employees dont get a bonus and have even received pay cuts. This company goes through predictable cycles of a few good years and then a few bad years revenue wise. The troubles all come from management - they are arrogant and not focused. They tell you how important the culture is at this company but they are telling you this from their rather large ivory towers.

Don't be fooled this company has no loyalty to you... 99% of the 30+ people I know that used to work there have moved on to better jobs elsewhere with more pay and more opportunity. While 99% of the people I know that still work there are in the same jobs or only made lateral moves or one bump in position. Good place to just collect a paycheck that will never change.

pros: The benefits are pretty good compared to other companies.  The insurance is good.  The pension has been changed twice in the last five years, but at least we have one.  If you are in the field you have a great opportunity to satisfy your customers.  You can build relationships and run your job like it is your own business.  There is a no layoff policy, although it is not written in stone.  The senior mgmnt. is invisible to people in the field.  There is no one looking over your shoulder when you do your job.  If you are a courier you are outside most of the time.
cons: This is a two tiered company.  Management vs. hourlies.  The frontline employees are viewed with utter contempt.  The managers micromanage everything.   The managers are kool-aid drinkers and many believe anything upper management tells them even when it makes no sense.  The benefits have slowly been whittled away from us.  No more profit sharing, no jumpseat benefit, no survivor income benefit, no Individual performance pay.  If you have surgery and go out on disability you get five sick pay days and then you have to go on STD. The vendor for Fedex treats you like a criminal.  Fedex chooses the low cost provider for benefits.

review_title: If you like to keep your head down this is a good place.
pros:
Job stability -- very difficult to lose one's job here.
401(k) employer match is decent.
Health insurance was ok, getting worse with consumer health plan in '14
If you work in a well-managed port, things can be really great.
cons:
Too fragmented and different modes don't speak the same language.
Some managers are too divorced from operations and make odd or silly decisions.
HR is out to lunch and some egregious employee behavior is not addressed timely.
Job descriptions don't match actual duties resulting in underpaid and overworked staff.
Compensation is too low for the level of knowledge required to do most jobs.
Training is not a priority despite the increasing demand for compliance by CBP, lots of out of pocket expenses to get the training needed to advance.
Antiquated computer systems - 20 yrs is too long to go without a major update.

job_title: Fed Ex Courier in Chicago, IL
pros: Independent work, time goes by fast, pension, insurance benefits, tuition reimbursement, can transfer anywhere in the country, lots of internal jobs to transfer into, great for a college student because of the 2nd shift jobs and tuition reimbursement.
cons: At the courier level, the job is only as good as the management. Most of the managers I have worked for have been extremely unprofessional. I suspect they are being asked to do impossible tasks, and it seems most of them can't handle the pressure when they pass on their requirements to the couriers. The managers are rude, impossible, inflexible, revengeful, and play favorites to the point where it makes the job not worth working there. Upper management does not deal with unprofessional management at the operations level effectively. Inept managers are allowed to retain their job for decades rather than remedial training, or termination. New employees who are hired as couriers will never make what I make now because fedEx has implemented a two-tier wage system. It's impossible for a new hire to ever top out. Only lip service is paid to improving the work process and environment through employee input. employees are simply told what to do whether the command has been thought through thoroughly or not.

review_title: If you like manual labor, this is a great place to work
pros:
Autonomy. 

Tuition Reimbursement.  

Good wage for unskilled labor (great for students)

Paid to exercise.  

Neat logo/uniforms/design.  

Reputable.  

I worked the PM sort alone at a small station through college--scanning and loading an average of about 750 packages in a 2.5 hour period.  You're graded for accuracy each night by comparing your (outbound) scans to the pick up scans done by the CSAs and Couriers--I believe 99.4% was the minimum goal--which means out of 750 packages and documents, you could only miss four to meet goal.  At my station, they don't randomly drug test handlers (unless you operate FedEx vehicles, or there is some type of accident).  Advancing isn't that difficult if you're a competent, hard worker--although FedEx is vehemently anti-union so if you like the idea of being a courier and committing to a company, UPS will pay more in the long run.  Express shipping is extremely expensive, so you're not unloading oddly shaped 140lbs packages all day (although it happens).
cons:
In the smaller stations, the amount of work required of you can border on insane.  

Stressful environment.  

They seem to go through low-level managers pretty quickly.  

Can be odd hours (Ramp workers have shifts at 3am, drivers are usually in the door at 6am).

review_title: 5 years in - Great Company, Antiquated Policies
pros:
- Low Stress Environment: nobody's competing or trying to steal your job
- Job Security: there is very little fear of being fired for being incompetent at a task. At worse, you fail and raise some gossip behind your back
- Work/Life Balance: depending on your team, sometimes you can go missing for days (unannounced) and nobody really bats an eye - benefit of the doubt, but don't push it
cons:
- Low Stress Environment: nobody wants to do any innovative or challenging work outside their job description
- Job Security: since no one thinks they can get fired, no one takes initiative on anything that doesn't come directly from their manager - and even then, challenging may ensue
- Pay Plateau: be wary and do the math first. Whatever salary you enter making will not change much over the course of time. Promotions are more time-based than merit, so it doesn't really matter if you do a great job or not...just do your time and you'll get there, 3% (yearly) or 7% (promotion) at a time. Until you hit your payband cap at least - then you're just stuck forever.

review_title: Good job if you have no asiprations other than a paycheck.  Those with ambition look elsewhere.
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: Flexibility - Fedex is very casual and laid back.  Unless you work in dot-com or other critial business areas you'll work 40 hours or less a week.
cons: Politics, micromanagement, meetings -  it depends on which area you work but getting ahead at FedEx is about who you know and who you network with at FedEx.  The secret to getting ahead at FedEx is to make it your life, bleed orange and purple, be on your blackberry 24/7/365 to your mgrs.  Excessive reporting on your activities.  Each month I have 2 meetings with my director on project updates, monthly dashboard updates, weekly timekeeping and weekly project meetings.  Anything less and you'll be branded a "cowboy" or not a team player.  More time is spent on how you do things vs. getting the work done.

pros: You get paid every Friday and part-time benefits are better than a lot of jobs full-time benefits (Health, dental, and vision!
cons: Depending on the manager, some are lazier then others. Men will do more physical work then the women ALL THE TIME! In December they call it BLACK OUT, meaning starting the second week in December until after Christmas you will NOT be able to take any days off PERIOD! Also FedEx fiscal year starts June 1st and ends May 31st, so everyone has to bid on days off for their vacation. So it goes by seniority which means if you were hired after everyone in the company you will get wants left for the days off. meaning if two people already put in for those vacation days you won't even have a chance to get those days off. This happens every year! One guy I work with has been wanting to get Thanksgiving Eve & Christmas Eve off for the last 5 years, but because two other people have been with the company a little while longer and request those day every year HE NEVER GETS THOSE DAYS OFF! He has a family with young kids!

review_title: Enjoyed the people (co-workers and customers), the company did not involve the ops side of the business in decesions.
pros: Great benefits, however the benefits were not the same for FedEx Office as they were for the FedEx's parent company.  Training was good and on=going, both on=line and occasional classroom training.  Advancement opportunity was great, they truly promote from within.
cons: On the FedEx Office side, FedEx did not involve the opeartions side in any decesions they rolled out that could affect their customers or co=workers.  Unrealistic goals were set for stores to achieve in the area of sales, again this is where involvement would be helpful.  Store management would have been able to offer information that should have been considered when setting budgets for their areas (local economy, competition, etc.).  Too much change, SOP's would change weekly, I would describe it a the spagetti test.  They would roll out a new policy or process and not wait long enough to test the process before changing it again (throw spagetti at a wall and not wait long enough to see if it would stick).  They lost credability with co-workers and made it difficult to manage and hold co-workers accountable with the constant changes.

review_title: FedEx is a GREAT place to hang your hat.
pros: It is a great company where employees are valued. Employees are rewarded based on performance. So a good, hard worker with lots of initiative will find a very favorable environment for lots of personal and professional growth. Their commitment to people is deep. Letting an employee go, or a group of employees, is only ever done as a very last resort. The benefits package is one of the best, and it is still mostly paid for by the company. There are many opportunities for special recognition and reward. The bonus program is based on performance of the company as well as the employee.
cons: It is a corporation. So some of the same problems of red tape and policy slowdowns that exist at other corporations exist here. Also, being a corporation, there are some silo'd groups within the organization. But upper management has been working to resolve those silo issues for the past few years. While a motivated and talented person will find the performance based atmosphere very beneficial, someone just looking for a place to collect a paycheck will find an environment that moves and adapts quickly. If you are looking for a repetitive, predictable task job, you won't find what you are looking for here. Be prepared for new adventures and challenges every few weeks.

review_title: The worst place to work unless you like carrying others (Memphis employee reviews are happy as Springfield carries them)
job_title: Senior ECO Import Agent in Springfield, MO
pros: Always work to be done.
cons:
- Excessive overtime that is mandatory.
- Required to "assist" others to get their work done.  No self accountability, and this only applies to the favorites.
- Favoritism.
- Next to no room for advancement.
- Wages are about 20 years behind.  In no way competitive for the responsibility and knowledge required for the position.
- GM only supports the growth of people like her, and if you are any different she will ensure you do not advance and your get nickel and penny raises.  The worst in favoritism.  She fires people for not doing things that even she cannot handle in her position.
- New hires get hired on for more than tenored staff makes after 10+ years of service.
- The office is much like high school and has lots of cliques.  If you aren't "popular" people will treat you bad.
- Mistreatment by other employees will never be addressed by management. Despite all the politically correct information in the handbook, they will allow other employees to bully individuals.  
- Your family and personal life must come last.  Unless again you are part of the popular crowd, then you are allowed long lunches to go shopping.

cons: overall I'm satisfied , If there was a down sideit would be that  there are not a lot of oppurtunities for the front line employees to move into sales without previous sales expereince. This really impedes people that have been with the company for a long time. I believe there should be a mentorship program that brings the front line employees and sales group together. THere are enough skills test that exist in the world that one would have to write a test see if they are compatiable with sales, if so they should be given a chance to develope those skills without having to leave the company. review_title: Great place for a person that willing  to work hard
pros: Great pay once you put some time in. Benefit are very good. This is a job that no matter what level you are at you will likely have to hustle,  but it's nice to know that everyone is working as hard as you are and very few people have time to play around. I like my job because it is very interesting and no day is like the other.
cons: Starting out as a package handler is very hard work most can do it in short term but very few  have what it take to make a career of it. Moving up beyond a package handler with out a degree is very hard if not impossible in some facilities. I know some that have been with the company for over 6 years and still never made it past  package handler with a degree. They only want a certain type of person in managament rolls so if you don't fit the mold your out of luck.

pros: Great managers, flexible work conditions, friendly climate amongst colleagues
cons: Cost cuts, difficult career progression

review_title: A job to pay the bills
pros: It's a good, physical job that is rewarding when you step back and see how much you do in a day. Every day is different, with changing challenges and new experiences. The company always hires from within so if you're willing to work hard and climb the ladder this is a great opportunity.
cons: The hours will destroy your social life. Although it's normal for a salary position to work more then forty hours a week it's when the hours happen during the day that is the killer. My current position is from 1 P.M.-10 P.M. Mon-Fri so forget going out at night with spouse, family or friends during the week and doing all of your errands in the morning. The other option is from 10 P.M.-6 A.M. which may give you the better part of your evening back but it takes a certain type of person to do a job this physical on a third shift schedule.

job_title: Part-time Package Handler in Norcross, GA
pros: Great place to work at. Great management. Manager and supervisors are very friendly. They makde sure you work, but they don't push you to your limits, and they usually don't make you work overtime. Work is fast-paced, but not extremely fast. Do the best you can, don't stand around daydreaming and you'll be fine. If you're not used to activate work YOU WILL FEEL IT THE FIRST DAY, but after a day or two, your body will get accustomed to it and you'll barely feel a thing. Do wear protective gear: gripping gloves and FOREARM SLEEVES, I personally recommend the latter to avoid too much bruising. Pay is decent, and you get A LOT of good benefits even as a part-time employee, provided that you stay a while. If you're looking for a part- time job, LOOK NO FURTHER, FedEx is the place to be! Also worth mentioning, is how easy it is to get hired. I was hired after a week of attending a Sort Observation. When they call you back, show them that you're interested and you're basically in.
cons: Early AM Shift: Loss of sleep. Rough, tiresome first day. Not for the lazy.

review_title: Good company but the halo is questionable.
pros:
Integrity of executive leadership
People Service Profit culture and respect of persons
Some working flexibility
cons:
Very difficult to advance and grow, many people are frustrated. Structure internal interview process favors those who learn the process over merit and ability. Little incentive to move laterally results in in-breeding in many - not all - departments.
Push to broaden management span has decreased management opportunities.
Executive leadership has had a history of putting profit above people while stating the opposite. Promised bonus has not been paid at  100% for over ten years. No visibility into the bonus process despite the CFO's video communications, which only results in further questions. 
People Service Profit culture is lip service with many vps, directors, and managers.
Remote working opportunities have been restricted.
Many aspects of the culture and working environment are stuck in the 80s and 90s,
Nepotism - the chairman's son started at a hard-to-get principal position and is the fastest-rising executive  with apparently no competition for positions.

pros: Wonderful co-workers, good overall culture, good benefits on par with other companies), interesting work
cons: Upper management, low wages, little room for growth unless you relocate to HQ thanks to recent changes by upper management

pros: Perks are great. You get about 5 raises the first year. Very flexible schedule, you work Monday thru Friday but if you need a day off your manager has your back. Fun if youre with the right people. SUPER EAZY TO GET INTO THE JOB. We get free food all the time and t-shirts!
cons: If you do the math...the amount of hours + the amount of pay + plus the amount of physical labor you do = not worth it for me. I'm 5'2 and weigh a little of 100lbs. And I've been doing this job for the past 3 months, and I've done really good. Except for I'm broke and I can't wear shorts because I'm covered in bruises and people think I get abused at home. It's a decent in between jobs job. also, it might be easy to move up but you can't apply for another position until you've been there for at least 6 months. They make it out to be your fault if you get injured on the job but will throw a fit if you don't report it.

review_title: A Lot Depends on Location & Managers - Some are Better than Others
job_title: Fed Ex Ground Package Handler in Chillicothe, OH
pros: Easy to get hired.  Short shifts make it great for some people.   The pace is usually nonstop and intense, filling up the whole shift.  At our location, there is a core of very hard working people who assist and support one another.  You get benefits as a part time employee.
cons: You cannot live on this job alone.  The work is physical and demanding and can do some harm to your body.  The manager plays favorites and some people get away with doing as little as possible.  It is dirty and you are exposed to the elements in the winter.  Very little chance for advancement and not enough hours to support existence.  Peak Season can easily burn you out.

pros: Great Job great company and pay
cons: none, great place to work at

pros: Good work life balance environment
cons: Limited growth opportunities in my experience

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros:
Great benefits and if you do your job (not even well) you can count on staying employed.  The salary is competitive and the company is good at what it does.

Many good managers - great work-life balance.  They really do care about their staff.
cons:
There are a lot of old timers (20+ yrs) that won't quit - no matter how many buy outs are offered.  This is a constant frustration since there is little focus put on getting ahead of the competition in the digital arena.  Many middle management are stone walls for progress and are overly concerned with (outdated) process adherence and internal metrics that only impact year end internal goals - not based on progress in the market.  There are some GREAT managers - but a bad managing director can and often will skunk up the teams beneath them.  

More meetings than are needed and far too many obstacles to innovation.

If you like a fast pace and modern tech - you need to look into the marketing team - the Services/TechConnect side will only frustrate you.

review_title: Undervalued, monotonous work with okay benefits
pros:
The training is nice, but depending on the department you are going to, could be completely useless.
Co-workers generally nice and helpful, though you may get in trouble for asking them questions on the floor, as management theory is that no one knows what they're doing.
3 weeks vacation, 10 sick and 6 floating holidays. When those benefits start depend on your hire month. You can go maybe 6 months without vacation, depending on your start date, but that is pretty normal.
cons:
Work is monotonous, as is most data entry, can't say it wasn't expected.
Stressful to be both efficient (lots of files processed) and accurate (zero mistakes, even human error typos count against you).
Little room for career advancement.
Monthly reviews are meant to be helpful but come across as either punishment or an excuse to pile on extra work if you perform well for no extra benefits.

pros: You can earn a paycheck.
cons: The company discourages forming a union at orientation. They pay to little for the amount of work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in City of Industry, CA
pros: Quite a diverse array of people from all backgrounds. Pretty flexible with people's schedules.
cons: There have been a few occasions where I was called to come in because a manager thought he was overwhelmed. By time I got there things were normal. Extremely poor judgement call on management's side. I've learned to avoid the phone now and I've lost confidence in the person as a leader. Fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me. Work-life balance is fairly good except during "peak" times. Promotion is hardly based on merit. A lot of favoritism at the place I work at. For example, a lot of family members have become management in a blink of an eye.

pros: It is a good company with excellent benefits.
cons: I worked for five years and I had to quit when I had my twin babies since unfortunately the Human Resource Department did not want to give me a better option to stay with my babies for at least two more months after my FMLA expired even with a letter from the Doctor about the necessity of being more time taking care of the babies as they were still too little.  I was wrongfully treated by this HR manager when I tried to go and say goodbye to my co-workers and drop off my ID, like if I was leaving the company in bad terms. I feel a big dissatisfaction in the way the company let me leave and after five years of good work and sacrifice I was treated in a wrong way " like if instead of giving five good years of exceptional work and compromise with the company, I was stealing something or offend in any way to my employer ".

pros: FedEx offers a competitive salary and the opportunity for advancement within the organization.  In a relatively short amount of time you are able to progress from a part time employee to a full time manager.  In addition, FedEx offers loads of useful training and college-type courses for personal growth.  Further, the company also offers compensation beyond hourly wage and benefits in the form of college tuition reimbursement, discounts, travel benefits, and more.
cons: Some of the detractors of working for FedEx would be the hours; often they can be unpredictable and vary especially when you are part time working towards full time, or when you are a swing driver.  There are also at times issues with staffing and the overloading of work on employees.  One can however understand that to keep the company going and competetive you must keep labor costs lower and productivity higher.

pros: none at all pretty bad
cons: several problems and bad management

pros: No meat all what so ever
cons: Everything from management to job

pros: None. Left after three months.
cons: Females are harassed. Management does not care about workers.

pros: Something is always screwed up, so even part-timers can usually get all the hours they want. If you like to keep moving all day this job is for you. The medical benefits are crap now, but that's not peculiar to FedEx. Even part-time hires immediately get the same medical as everyone else. No dangling carrot mirages, you get hired, you've got medical. 2 weeks vacation, 3 after 5 years, 4 at 10 years, 5 at 20.  You CAN start at the bottom and work your way up to work group manager, senior manager, regional director, division vice president. Virtually all middle management is hired from within.
cons: Management varies WILDLY. It's a crap shoot if you have a good manager or a nut job.  If you get injured on the job they will NOT have your back.  If you like Christmas, forget about being a courier, for ANY company.

pros: Good wages and local management.  I would recommend FedEx to a friend and have.
cons: Some micro-management from upper management.  Benefits have lessened over the past few years and it is rare now to get 100% of bonus.  Usually attain between 25-50% now since they changed how it is paid out.  When I started 100 -120% attainment was considered normal.  It used to be based on station performance alone.  Now it is based on local, operating company performance, and corporate performance.  If FedEx decides to buy 100 new planes, it now affects your bonus.  I wouldn't mind the new structure as long as it was attainable.  Seems like they always have a reason for not paying out complete bonuses, even when then company is doing well.  We haven't come close to 100% since they changed it.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Orlando, FL
pros: Good pay and weekly checks.
cons: Extreme working environments. Strenuous work with no break.

review_title: Great company to work for if you are looking to have balanced life/work environment.
pros: Workload is shared and many senior stuff members who can be good support system for junior stuff. Very stable company to work for as lay offs may be the last item on the CEOs list of cost cutting measures, he seems to care a bit about the employees.
cons: Wouldn't recommend for new college graduates who are still fresh & looking to develop their job skills quick as there's tendency to specialize in few job roles and not too exciting for workaholics, u may be bored with no work to do at times. Low stuff turnover, meaning very limited opportunities for growth to the next level.

pros:
Promote from within
Easy to get hired
cons:
No breaks
Hard work with unreasonable expectations
NO A/C

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Charlotte, NC
pros: the pay is pretty good.
cons: it was always hot. and some of the stuff was heavy.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Olathe, KS
pros: There are no pros here
cons: Terrible environment and terrible managers.

review_title: A great company going through some tough times
pros: You work with a great team, the salary and benefits are excellent.  They almost always promote from within, although the road getting there can be pretty tough (as it should be).  You really get to have an impact on your employees' lives, and you can feel like you're part of a family if you stick around long enough.
cons: No home life whatsoever.  Some very hard choices have to be made at the end of the fiscal year when suddenly budgets shrink and everyone at the corporate level wants you to do more with less.  High octane, high stress environment with little to no downtime.  They give you a laptop and a cell phone and you had better be attached to them 24/7.  High turnover rate among managers, who seem to get fired extraordinarily easily.

job_title: Senior Strategic Marketing Analyst in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Good hours/ benefits, flexible vacation time, employee discounts (airline, car purchase), workload is not difficult if you have any kind of good work ethic/ intelligence
cons: Promotions only available to IT-type people or if you kiss up to the manager, project work/ performance review system is a joke, same mundane job day in and day out, no working from home because certain people abused the privelege so now nobody can do it, incompetent management/ director, too many "lifers" that can't carry their own workload - but they are not reprimanded or fired, everyone gets the same 3% raise every year - regardless of performance, if you are a productive worker - you get rewarded with MORE WORK, and you get to do the lifer's work since they don't care to do it.

review_title: Multi-tasking, fast-paced, personable, but often too stressful
pros: Very inclusive company, positive working environment, encourages teamwork and has solid ethical enforcement. Management is selected well. Build consistent and positive relationships with regular customers, and really feel like you're helping them out with high-priority situations, from important shipments to wedding invitations and funeral memorials.
cons: Often understaffed to meet customer needs; multiple customers in different parts of the store, all needing your help at the same time when you're understaffed and have deadlines to meet for shipping AND printing needs -- very stressful. Customer Service doesn't communicate consistent protocols that retail stores need to operate under. Job is already stressful enough as is with so much multi-tasking involved, but then you're also expected to push sales of specific items each month, plus packing services (when you sometimes don't even have proper time to package items).

pros: None sucks cart bananas foot
cons: Working there all day every day pizza

job_title: Senior Marketing Proj Analyst  in Memphis, TN
pros:
Great work life balance. Sr Mgmt encourages a lot of community work. 
Good pay. Cost of living is pretty low compared to major cities. Pay hikes are pretty low. 
Interesting Business problems. Constantly changing economic landscapes has us doing a lot of analytics to support business decisions. Strong analytics forms the backbone of a number of group in fedex.
Lot of focus on employee training and developing leadership. Management is very friendly and easily accessible. every major life event (marriages, birthdays, babies) are celebrated with a lot of joy. Lot of ongoing community work during office hours as part of corporate responsibility.
Very diverse culture - lots of women and minorities in the work place.
cons:
Career growth can be slow. Very few mgmt openings and too many professionals vying for them.
Company pursues too many projects and there are lot of resource issues.The operate independently model hampers a lot of initiatives. The hierarchy is pretty flat at the top and lot of issues cannot be resolved by top management due to the flat structure.
very different cultures across opcos.

review_title: Ok if you like to get burned out for little pay
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Haven, CT
pros: Interesting people thats about it.
cons: They work you to the bone, especially during peak which usually starts end of October through end of January. Basically your there from 6am to about 7-9pm. The contractors pay about 1.25-1.50 a stop. Depending on the day you could have between 70-180 stops(stops not packages, you could have 1 stop and have 10 packages to drop off). Its great if you can work under 6-7 hours, but anything over that your about 8-9$ an hour in the end. Totally not worth it. Contractors make a lot and the more routes they own the more bling. Not sure what they got exactly but when your living in a nice 4-5 bedroom house, own/lease 3-4 luxury cars BMW, Land Rover and Mercedes and own all the toys, you must be making over 250-350k a year if not more.  Its fine if you want no life, single and like to drive around. The trucks are hot in summer and cold in the winter (if you have newer truck you should be fine).

review_title: A great company to be at!
pros: There isn't much I can't say! I've never worked for a company this amazing. I've had a lot of different jobs and coming to Fedex has been a beautiful wake up. This will be the place I retire from. 'The FedEx way' was shown to me the first two weeks in the door. 99.9 percent of people I have met have been nothing but kind and love their jobs! Resources are everywhere and encouraged to use! This company treats you like family and has strong family values. Positive encouragement is passed out on a regular basis and negativity is not welcome. The benefits are outstanding! Management and above listens to everyone and your effort is appreciated. The team activities are fun and never feel forced. I am so grateful to be part of the Fedex family. If you have the chance - don't miss out!
cons: Pay is a little low for the field. The interview process can be overwhelming and can make you almost walk away. Don't! The cons really aren't here. If the pay was a tad higher I think this company would literally be the top company to work for!

pros: Steady hours, decent health benefits.
cons: The pay situations are garbage.  I started with the company as a package handler. After getting a degree, I moved up to a Maintenance position. HR has told me that there is a "cap" as to how much you can increase pay. So I am forever below the pay rate of people who came from the outside. I've even trained new employees who started off making $4+ per hour MORE than me; just because they worked for a completely different company for 20 years (no experience in this field). FedEx can learn something from Unions. Cut & dry requirements. You can't do the job, you don't get the pay.

review_title: Still absolutely, positively after all the years
pros: Company culture is great, very positive towards customers and employees. We're all in it together. The old "absolutely, positively" ethic is still alive at FedEx. Cost of living is low compared to pay for the Memphis area locations. Benefits are good, especially work life balance. My manager always says, "Work to live, don't live to work." FedEx is one of the largest shipping companies in the world, so we get to work on some of the largest, most interesting business challenges in the world.
cons: FedEx (and its divisions) are a very large, mature company. Bureaucracy is the norm for large companies. It is easy to get lost in the masses. Advancement opportunities can be hard to find in many parts of the corp, unless you have a senior manager champion who wants you promoted. There is an entrenched good-old-boy network which can be hard to crack. Look out if/when Fred Smith retires.

job_title: Cross Border E-Commerce Agent in Memphis, TN
pros:
•Interesting work
•Relaxed environment 
•Rapport among coworkers
cons:
•Overstaffed
•Work is repetitive
•False 
•Poor communication and consistency from management 
•Less than adequate business resources and aid materials
•Noticeable gap between high performers and others yet no rewards for those that perform at a higher level or go above and beyond 
•Holidays were taken away, and, at times, overtime is mandated  
•Favoritism shown by management 
•Pay is not as high as similar positions in other companies
•No opportunities for advancement in company
•Special projects only given to select group of people
•Lack of true management on certain shifts

pros: it suck really bad bad
cons: i will never work there again

job_title: Technical Advisor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great company. I was proud to work for them. However, I think it is built on the back of the couriers, pilots, and hub people and delivers packages on time despite current poor IT support.
cons: The company has become mired in the mud due to new processes implemented over the last few years. It is impossible to get anything done for the users. Small fixes take an act of Congress to load to production, much more than they are worth. So anything but the most fatal of errors is never scheduled for work. Paperwork occupies most of a developers time. Don't go there if you like to make things *work* for your users.

job_title: Ramp Agent in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: There are some good attributes to working for FedEx when you are part time.  For example you will have 2 personals, 2 floating holidays, and 2 weeks vacation, 401k and health benefits.
cons: I have worked at several locations at my current 11 years, and the one things that all of them have in common is that the ramp agents are abused on a daily basis.  As a ramp agent your are responsible for running the sort and have almost 4 pages of job responsibilities for a whopping 15:85 an hour starting with a 30 cent raise every year.  You are responsible for keeping handlers in line, but you can't fire or discipline them but you are responsible for their actions and held 100% accountable.

pros: The people are amazing. Management really cares about their people, helping them to learn and grow. What you think is really hard is not. I left seeking more money. I work twice the hours with less appreciation and the work is so much harder. At some point you have to decide what is important. If it is family and security with work/life balance and a place that encourages great customer service and volunteerism - stay at FedEx! I had 6 weeks vacation that I was encouraged to use. I will never ever get that again.
cons: When you have been here for 10 years you see other, "newer models" coming in and making more money than you do. It is really discouraging. All I wanted was market value for my hard work and couldn't get it. They backfilled my position, turned over two people and then ended up paying more than what I asked for.

pros: It is like being part of a professional sports team at FedEx Ground. Management doesn't force too much down your way, but you are an essential cog of the wheel. It is an easy job to get, but it takes art and strength to keep it past even the trial period. If you get good and do it correctly, it is a great exercise.
cons: The primary position requires that you scan 300 barcodes an hour and lift 70 lbs. quite regularly and if you can't take that you will not be around long. Most people actually do make it. There are sirens and the constant noise of the conveyor, earplugs might save the valuable hairs of your inner ear.

pros: Solid company to work for, competitive base salary compared to some other sales roles, good culture overall, ramp up period is understanding that there's going to be a learning curve. Travel benefits are very unique and cool.
cons: Bonus (commission) structure is confusing and often you have little control over whether your customers ship more, less, or the same. You could have an amazing quarter with on-boarding new business and not make a bonus check because 1 or 2 of your customers changed the way they billed their shipments. Salespeople are not always rewarded for their efforts. Company has no flexibility with working from home or conducting meetings via online or phone - everything must be done in person every day of the week.

review_title: Other than keeping your Job, working hard doesn't benefit you here.
pros: Money was good for what you were doing. You get a raise for just staying for longer than a month. Job is very easy mentally, you just put boxes on a belt. Your work days never changed, so you always knew your schedule. Management were lenient when asking for days off.
cons: Managers were nice one day, but very rude and disrespectful the next. Managers in a sense are slave drivers, meaning no matter how ahead of schedule or how hard you work, they wanted you to work harder. Managers get angry if you start to slow down slightly after lifting 50 Ib boxes straight for two hours. Overall just a lot of disrespect and lack of constructive motivation from managers. Aside from management, working there in winter is bitter cold. The job is also very repetitive.

pros: There were no pros working there
cons: unprofessional manager, very low hours

pros: They provide marketing and business for your delivery business.
cons: Fedex continually increases the delivery load and other responsibilities they place upon the contractors in order to increase their profits, without any concern whatsoever for how it affects the contractors.  In fairness to local management, they probably have their hands tied as more and more volume is generated in their area without the terminal being awarded adequate PSA's to cover it, so they are forced to either run supplemental routes which mean additional payroll, rental, insurance, and fuel expenses, or their drivers end up working past the hours allowed by DOT.

pros: Work life balance is required, most managers are really nice and understanding. Benefits are good, standby flight benefits on all airlines.
cons: If you are unable or don’t want to move from Dallas, consider your career dead. There are virtually no positions to promote to, and too many politics and higher ups with power struggles. Unable to control your numbers, it seems like they draw names from a hat to see who gets a bonus, internal issues are unreal for a company this size. The director is a nightmare, she is anti-family, anti-team work, if she had it her way we would be glued to our desks all day. They also changed the bonus payout and they don’t care how that money affects our families.

pros: Good time off to be with family
cons: Bad management and mangers that’s

pros:
- Deep corporate resources for equipment, supplies, job tools
- Good education benefits
- Good bonuses (if the company is doing well)
- Tries to improve
- Has some agile, intelligent, hard-working employees
cons:
- Moves ponderously slowly (if at all) on intelligent suggestions from the experts the company employs
- Misses ENORMOUS money-making opportunities because of management turf wars
- Moves lightning-fast on pet projects promoted by upper management
- Wastes money investing in poorly managed and under-analyzed initiatives
- Terrible at follow-through on long-term projects
- Terrible at internal communications (can be very "siloed")
- You need to be excellent at tooting your own horn to advance
- Annual employee reviews are more a matter of defending yourself rather than collaborating with management and documenting your successes and learning experiences
- Awards and advancement can be based on favoritism and the "halo" effect
- Management quality is spotty
- Has shockingly few safeguards/redundancies in place to ensure quality/thoroughness of work

pros: Fed Ex gives students like me the flexibility to be a full time student, while working part time and having all of the perks of a full time employee. Not to many jobs out there will give you full benefits (health, dental, vision)from the day you start. Fed Ex helps with tuition reimbursement (up to $3,000 per year).  You also get flight benefits if you are over the age of 21 years old, and have been with the company up to 6 months. The flight benefits allowed me to travel to places through any airline at 75% off the total cost of any plane ticket.
cons: Fed Ex is an extremely physical job, with high risks of injury day in and day out if not cautions at all times. The entry level pay can be a higher for the amount of work provided. Starting pay is not far from minimum wage in the Bay Area.

pros: They have very good benefits
cons: They don’t care for their employees.

review_title: Great place to work with a lot of flexibility
pros: Lots of flexibility on hours, relocation, and promotion.  Generally good people and a world-class service brand.  I had worked for the "major competitor" for many years, and found the FedEx workplace and culture to be much more open and motivated.
